Comment: This game was played in a Thematic MT hosted by Jongraft.  The initial position starts after 4. Nxd4
I'm sure this game may prove to have errors & missed opportunities for both sides.  However, it was fun to play & has a dramatic ending.

Well I guessed right, but 20.Qe6  might have been better.
Pinning the Rook with the idea of Ng5

I was pleased to see this move.  It told me that Black was overconfident in his position & wanted to counter-attack my Queen-side.  Not until analysis did I see 21...Nd4 leading to 

22.Qg4   Kh8
23.Nxd4  Qxd4
24.Qxd4  exd4

The material comes off, I'm up a Bishop & a pawn; but the win is far from clear.
Pinning his Knight & giving him trouble in hope that he will further commit to the Queen-side attack.

It worked.  Now when I play Ng5 & the Queen comes to c7 in defense, I can trade off.  So now my plan is...

Ng5  Qc7
Qxf7   Qxf7
Nxf7   Kxf7
Rxb4

I'll be up a Rook, Bishop, & a pawn.  The win might be several moves away, but it's clear.  I just force trades until I'm the only one who has material left.
Attacking the pinned Rook as planned.
At this point alarm bells start ringing in my head.  Black is in trouble.  Both of his Rooks are attacked, 1 of them is pinned.  There might be a mating attack here, but I can't quite see it.
I figure I'll take his Rook; let Black re-capture, pinning his other Rook.  Then maybe I can bring one of my Rooks into the attack.

Well I wanted to bring a Rook in, now I can do it with tempo.

Nxd6   Kh8
Rxe5
